<speak>
    Sermon Two: On the Purification of the Blessed Virgin Mary<break time="500ms"/>
</speak>
chunks.original_latin:
SERMO II
(ut habetur in ms etsi dubio titulo). In Purificatione beatae Virginis Mariae.

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
This feast honors the same person as those and is equally important. We will clearly demonstrate this with evidence in this sermon. The solemnity of this day, though unknown to some Christians, is highly honored by many above other feasts of the year. Especially in the place where the Catholic Church has its leader, it is observed with such reverence that on this day, the entire city gathers together, their candles shining brightly, to celebrate the solemnity of the Mass. No one enters the public place without holding a light, as if they were to present the Lord in the temple, or rather to receive Him; they show the light of faith, which shines within, through the outward sign of their offering.

Today, according to the law and the gospel, forty days after Christ's birth, the Lord was presented in the temple by His parents. Today, He was received by Saint Simeon and offered to the Father with sacred gifts. Today, Simeon and Anna proclaimed the redemption expected by the people of Israel. Oh, what a loving sight, which only the devout truly enjoy! Here stands the virgin and mother, not of just anyone, but of God. Here the child, the virgin's son, is received, whose divinity the world cannot contain. Here prophets come forward, and both men and women prophesy about the child. An offering is made for the child, not to cleanse sins but to declare the sacraments.

And because I wish to elevate the praise of this day, I would like to go through the Gospel reading in conversation, knowing these things are narrated, so that what I say may correspond with it; indeed, so that my words of exhortation may align with what it narrates.

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
Finally, Luke, the evangelist, offers a more detailed and orderly account of Christ's incarnation than the other evangelists. After the angel's announcement in the year 669, the birth heralded by angels, and the circumcision on the eighth day at his parents' home, Luke continues: "When the days of her purification according to the Law of Moses were completed, they brought him to Jerusalem to present him to the Lord, as it is written in the Law of the Lord, 'Every male that opens the womb shall be called holy to the Lord'" (Luke 2:22-23).

It's clear to all believers that the Redeemer's mother was untouched by any stain from his birth, as she didn't need purification by staying away from sacred places during that time. Because, without human desire or corruption of the flesh, the virgin gave birth and remained a virgin forever; thus, no male was born from her to open her womb. Yet, while narrating the law, the evangelist doesn't reveal the divine incarnation's mystery to the impious but shows the mother observing the law. It's not surprising that she would follow the law her Son came not to abolish, but to fulfill. She knew how she conceived and who she had given birth to. But by observing the common law, she awaited the purification day, concealing her son's majesty. That's why, when she found him in the temple at age twelve, she referred to him as Joseph's son, saying: "Son, why have you done this to us? Look, your father and I have been searching for you in sorrow" (Luke 2:48). She undoubtedly knew she conceived him without Joseph's involvement and gave birth without any loss of her virginity.

But why did she conceal the mystery of his conception and birth, knowing he was the boundless God? Did she envy others when she brought him to the temple and entrusted him to the holy elder? Certainly not. Perhaps, filled with the spirit of prophecy, she chose not to reveal the world's redemption to the impious. For she already knew, full of grace and inspired by divine spirit, that if the rulers of this world had recognized him, they would never have crucified him for our salvation.

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
So, present him, most blessed Virgin, as one who follows the law, in the temple, whom you brought forth, so that not everyone but only a few may know who it is you have given birth to. Let the humble stone, cut from the mountain without hands, be revealed, so that it may be rejected by the builders until it strikes the statue on its feet, grows into a great mountain, and fills the entire world.

Oh, how small, oh, how great is he whom you have given birth to! Small in humanity, great in divinity; small in the kingdom of the Jews, great in the kingdom of the nations.

Yet not everyone in the kingdom of the Jews considers him small. For even you, who gave birth to him, grew from the same people of Israel into a branch. You rose as a branch from the root of Jesse and blossomed. Like Aaron's rod, you blossomed and bore fruit. Because you recognized his vastness above all, although you saw him born very small from you, without a doubt, you trembled and worshiped the Almighty God whom you bore as a baby. Worshiping, you trembled. Yet, because you recognized him as your son according to humanity, you nursed, cherished, and nurtured him.

Who, do you think, could reveal to us the feelings of your heart in such service, O most blessed Virgin? When, on one side, you saw the tiny infant born from you, and on the other side, beheld the immense God; here the created, there the creator; here the weak, there the very strong; here needing to be fed, there feeding; here not speaking, there teaching angels.

Who, I ask, can reveal to us the secrets of your heart, in what ways you turned your thoughts to both, as you held in your hands the one and the same Son of God and man, worshiping him as Lord on one side and kissing him as a little child on the other?

Who would not be amazed at such an ineffable miracle? Who would not almost be rendered speechless? A young girl gives birth to her creator and the creator of all, nourishes her nurturer and the nurturer of all, brings to the temple her ruler and the ruler of all. Oh, what a wondrous sight, at which not only human but even angelic nature is amazed!

To this, dearest brothers, lift your eyes of faith; to this, come with the affection of piety.

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
Receive Christ, who is humbled in the flesh for you, but worship Him as the exalted God in His divinity. Embrace the child, yet consider His immensity. Love the humbled one, and fear the exalted one.

Now truly, beloved, if we seek to understand the mystical meaning of why our Redeemer wanted to be carried by His mother and relatives from His own city to the temple of the Lord in Jerusalem, we find that the glorious mother and virgin, along with her relatives, represented the Church that believed in the apostles from among the Jews. For when is the Church not a virgin? The Apostle addresses its members, saying: "I am jealous for you with a godly jealousy, for I have promised you to one husband, to present you as a pure virgin to Christ" Second Corinthians chapter eleven, verse two.

When is she not a mother? As it is said through the Psalmist: "And of Zion it shall be said, 'This one and that one were born in her'" Psalm eighty-seven, verse five. And the Lord in the Gospel says: "For whoever does the will of my Father in heaven is my brother and sister and mother" Matthew chapter twelve, verse fifty.

When are the chosen ones not relatives, who are called brothers and sisters? Therefore, the mother and relatives of our Redeemer carry Him from Nazareth to the temple of the Lord in Jerusalem, because that early Church in the first disciples, rejected by the Jews, brought the knowledge of the same redemption to the nations. For the Church is rightly called Jerusalem, meaning Vision of Peace, not only from the Gentiles but also from the Jews, of which it is said through the Psalmist: "Jerusalem is built as a city that is closely compacted together" Psalm one hundred twenty-two, verse three.

She is also the temple, as it is said to the faithful through Paul: "The temple of God is holy, which you are" First Corinthians chapter three, verse seventeen.

Therefore, when the apostles come from Judea, announcing Christ to the nations, Jerusalem indeed meets Jerusalem, and the temple meets the temple, for they all are one city, Jerusalem, and one temple. In this city, and in this temple, Christ is presented by the apostles. Hence the Church itself speaks with the voice of the Psalmist, saying: "We have thought on your steadfast love, O God, in the midst of your temple" Psalm forty-eight, verse nine.

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
Imagine yourself in the heart of the church, which is your temple.

Whether you look at it from a historical perspective or a mystical one, the reason Christ was brought by his parents to the holy city and temple is clarified when we hear:

To offer a sacrifice as stated in the law of the Lord, a pair of turtledoves or two young pigeons. (Luke 2:24)

The law commanded that if someone couldn't afford a lamb, they could offer either a pair of turtledoves or two young pigeons to God. This offering was equally acceptable.

In this offering of birds, we see a foreshadowing of the ultimate sacrifice for the world's salvation, namely the Lord's passion, through which we are reconciled to God.

Paul speaks to the faithful about this sacrifice:

Walk in love, as Christ also has loved us and gave himself for us as an offering and a sacrifice to God, a sweet-smelling aroma. (Ephesians 5:2) And again: Who loved me, he says, and gave himself for me. (Galatians 2:20)

Since all the chosen are members of Christ, this offering of birds also symbolizes the mortification of the chosen ones, to whom the apostle says:

I urge you by the mercy of God to present your bodies as a living sacrifice, holy, pleasing to God. (Romans 12:1)

An offering of mortification is only acceptable to God if there is true faith and unity.

Thus, it is significant that the sacrifice, mystically offered for the Lord, is described as coming from turtledoves and doves.

In the turtledove, chastity is found, and in the dove, unity is valued.

The turtledove remains faithful to one mate, and the dove does not abandon the unity of the group.

Therefore, a Catholic Christian becomes a spiritual turtledove when they hold firmly to the true faith of the Trinity and reject heretical teachings as they would the impurity of fornication.

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
Then there will truly be a dove if it remains patient in the Catholic community until the end and stands firm against the challenges of temptation. This means that neither heretical corruption taints the purity of faith in the heart nor bitter disagreement disrupts the unity of the Church's chastity. This is, indeed, the Catholic Church, which holds its faith with one Lord like a lawful husband and grows the congregation of many in faith.

It continues: "And behold, there was a man in Jerusalem whose name was Simeon; this man was just and devout, waiting for the consolation of Israel, and the Holy Spirit was upon him. And it had been revealed to him by the Holy Spirit that he would not see death before he had seen the Lord's Christ. And he came by the Spirit into the temple" (Luke 2:25-27). Nothing less is attributed to this particularly holy man, who resides in Jerusalem, meaning the vision of peace. He is just through his works of faith, devout in reverence, attentive to the consolation of Israel, filled with the Holy Spirit, and strengthened by the Spirit's response regarding the command of the incarnate Word. Oh, with what fervent desire did this man await, according to the promise of the Holy Spirit, to see the Redeemer in the flesh! What urgency do we suppose was in his prayer that deserved to be assured by a divine response about the things he asked for? What were his continuous words of lament in holy preaching? For he did not cease to ask until he received a response regarding the things he sought.

Indeed, in past times, many were filled with a similar desire, as the Lord testifies to the disciples, saying: "Many kings and prophets wanted to see what you see and did not see it; and to hear what you hear and did not hear it" (Luke 10:24). But this was granted only to those who appeared at the last in the fullness of these times. But if we attentively consider the desire of the following saints, for whom to live is Christ and to die is gain (Philippians 1:21).

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
We see that they are just as eager to witness the divinity of the same Savior, much like his desire to be seen in the flesh. This is why Paul says, "I desire to depart and be with Christ, which is much better" (Philippians 1:23).

Similarly, the Psalmist expresses, "My soul thirsts for the living God. When shall I come and appear before the face of God?" (Psalm 42:2).

Who can see in one Simeon the many, where one represents all the elect; those who are now righteous through faith and action, reverent with future hope, and in awe of the coming consolation? The Holy Spirit is recognized as dwelling within them, as the Apostle says, "The love of God has been poured out into our hearts through the Holy Spirit who has been given to us" (Romans 5:5); and it is also said to the faithful, "Your bodies are temples of the Holy Spirit, who is in you, whom you have received from God" (First Corinthians 6:19).

They also receive a promise from the Holy Spirit that they will not see death before seeing the Lord's Christ. In this still imperfect life, with the grace of the Holy Spirit, they see with the eyes of faith the one who promised to be with them until the end of the age (Matthew 28:20), not as a small child in the flesh, but immeasurable in divinity. They echo the Apostle, "Though we have known Christ according to the flesh, yet now we know him thus no longer" (Second Corinthians 5:16).

They dwell in Jerusalem and, in the Spirit, come to the temple where Christ is presented. Truly, they are Jerusalem who dwell in Jerusalem; they are the temple who come to the temple, in whom and through whom Christ is received.

Briefly, brothers, we discuss these matters to avoid becoming a burden as we strive to highlight the sacraments of this day, and what is holy and pure. It goes on: "And when his parents brought in the child Jesus, to do for him according to the custom of the law, he took him in his arms and blessed God, and said: 'Now you dismiss your servant, Lord, according to your word in peace'" (Luke 2:27, 28, 29).

 dicitur: Corpora vestra templum sunt Spiritus
sancti, quem habetis ex Deo (I Cor VI 19). Quique
responsum accipiunt a Spiritu sancto non se visuros
mortem nisi prius videant Christum Domini: quia
in hac adhuc corruptibili vita, ejusdem Spiritus sancti
gratia revelante, apertis oculis fidei, eum qui se
cum illis usque in finem saeculi mansurum esse
(Matth XXVIII 20) repromisit aspiciunt, non jam carne
parvulum, sed divinitate immensum. Qui etiam cum
Apostolo dicunt: Etsi noveramus Christum secundum
carnem, sed jam nunc non novimus (II Cor V 16). Habitant etiam isti in Hierusalem, atque in Spiritu
in templum quo Christus introducitur veniunt. Ipsi
enim sunt Hierusalem qui habitant in Hierusalem:
ipsi et templum qui veniunt in templum, in quibus et
 a quibus Christus excipitur. 11. Breviter, fratres, ista percurrimus, ne dum
quae sunt hujus diei sacramenta, quodque sanctum
purumque praeconium indicare studuimus, cuilibet in
fastidium veniamus. Sequitur: Et cum introducerent
puerum Jesum parentes ejus, ut facerent secundum
consuetudinem legis pro eo, et ipse accepit eum in
ulnas suas, et benedixit Deum, et dixit: Nunc dimittis
servum tuum, Domine, secundum verbum tuum in pace
(Luc II 27 28 29).
